captions.text: You guys would never guess who's here; who's right here beside me!
Benny the Irish polyglot! In Columbus Ohio of course!
We've got a lot of footage coming! You know this is level up weekend!
Oh is it?
This is level up weekend! So you're going to be able to get some French in, some Spanish, some Chinese!
OK, we're on! Let's do it!
Alright guys, you know what time it is! You see-
It's time to level up!
You need dramatic introductions, so it's like "Previously..."
"Previously on Laoshu..."
Benny was in the car, when suddenly he got the surprising news.
"My word, are we going to level up?"
Join us for the exciting conclusion!
Where are you from?
China
Which part of China?
The South.
Like Guangdong area?
[Cantonese] Do you speak Cantonese?
A little bit.
[Mandarin] Can you speak Mandarin?
You speak Chinese well!
Oh, you're being too nice!
We're all learning Chinese - my friends and I.
Thanks, but I'm vegetarian, so...
We want to practice Spanish with you.
We're here in this mall to find people from all over, just to speak with them
and practice whatever. Spanish, Chinese, Italian, Portuguese...
Hey, where are you guys from?
China? South China? Guangdong area?
[Cantonese] Do you speak Cantonese? [Mandarin] Do you speak Mandarin?
Which city are you from?
Fujian
Which?
Fujian
You know, we're busy "We don't have time", we don't have any time right now.
But you talk a little and they are kind of curious. You know, you can see that kind of...
"Why is there a white guy and a black guy speaking Chinese with me in the middle of this mall?"
And there's this weird curiosity to continue the conversation,
Even though they are saying "We're a but busy right now"
She started talking! We were about to wrap it up, and she started-
When you learn languages, you can't just be at home and just learn it from books all the time.
You have to get out there and speak with people if you want to get better.
"I don't want to speak, I just want to be able to understand"; that's a different story.
But I can't ­ no way! I want to be able to interact with people.
Watch this. You see that couple sitting at that table.
You can't interrupt them while they're eating!
Uh huh! Watch this! I want to get some Hmong. They might be Hmong! Let me ask them
Excuse me - do you know where there's an arcade in this mall?
Arcade? I don't think there is?
There isn't an arcade here? I thought you said there was an arcade here!
Sorry man!
Oh Dave and Busters?
Just walk over there.
Hey, where are you guys from?
Here.
You from here? No, I mean originally.
From Vietnam.
[Vietnamese] Do you speak Vietnamese?
Yeah! Wow! That's impressive man!
Because I'm learning Vietnamese now.
But where?
At home. I don't have a teacher, so...
Where is she from?
She's from Cambodia. Cambodian Chinese.
Oh really?
You want to flip out some Cambodian
[Cambodian] Hello! So you speak...
He's busting out some Cambodian!
So you speak Cambodian?
Where'd you learn all that?
[Vietnamese] On my own.
I need to get me some of that Rosetta Stone!
Ha! I was waiting for that Rosetta Stone to come up!
You don't need Rosetta Stone, you've got your Rosetta Stone right here in front of you!
Really, that's all you need!
Let me tell you - we weren't looking for a video game arcade!
We came over here...
He's like "I've been punk'd!"
We came over here just to get to practice.
That's the reason we're in the mall. We're here to practice languages.
You get over the fear to talk to one person; you see it's not that big a deal.
The next time you do it, you hesitate a little bit less.
People don't realize that the whole shyness thing is not a stamp for life.
Sometimes it is a little bit of a self-fulfilling prophecy, where you tell yourself
"I'm too shy to go up to that person"
And the only reason you are not going up to that person is because you are telling yourself
That you are too shy. And it's a vicious circle.
If you ignore that for a second and just walk up to someone and open your mouth.
You'd see, it' not that big a deal.
If I see Brazilians, I would just say
[Portuguese] "Hey man! What are you doing here?"
And start talking to them in Portuguese, and it works out great.
Oh look! Level up on the escalator!
Go for it man! Right behind you!
Hey, do guys know what time this mall closes?
You don't know what time? Eight?
Cause it's a Sunday and they normally close at 9.
Where are you guys from?
India? Which part?
South India.
Tamil Nadu?
[Tamil] Do you speak Tamil?
We speak Hindi.
[Hindi] Do you speak Hindi?
Because I also learn Hindi.
But my Hindi is really bad.
That's very good!
What are your names?
My name is Moses.
Nice to meet you!
She's reading Chinese!
Moses! I know you're hungry, but­
Excuse me, do you know what time this mall closes?
I have no idea - it's Sunday - probably six or seven.
Ah, it's Chinese!
[Mandarin] Can you speak Mandarin?
Yes I do.
Where are you from in China?
Hong Kong
[Cantonese] Ah, so you can speak Cantonese!
You can speak pretty good! Have you been there a long time?
Actually, I've never been to Hong Kong, so I study Cantonese at home all the time.
But I want to go there in the future.
But I think you speak Mandarin better than Cantonese?
I don't know.
I've already studied Mandarin for a long time.
What about those two?
[Mandarin] I speak Mandarin.
My husband brought in­
[Mandarin] Hey! Speak Chinese!
My husband brought Chinese students here for shopping.
They're going to come here shopping in the next half an hour or so
About 40 of them.
Forty??
You want to wait for them? You can practice your Chinese!
How long were you in China?
I've never been to China.
I spent 3 months in Taiwan, then I spent 2 months travelling to many places by train­
Which places did you go to?
Oh­ in mainland China....
And­ all advertisements in Spanish!
Hey, what is this right here?
It's chicken.
We want to practice Spanish with you!
Where are you guys from?
I'm Irish.
I'm American.
Where are you from?
Mexico.
OK. I only spent one day in Mexico city
How much is a water?
This one is 69c.
OK, then there are three here
What's up boss!
[WOLOF] Hello / [French] How are you?
[French] I'm good. Are you Senegalese?
No, I'm American, but I study Wolof and French.
[Wolof] I want to speak Wolof,
[French] But...
Did you learn that in Africa?
No - here! He studied at home all by himself!
Here, in Columbus?? You've never been to Africa?
No.
Wow.
I was in his house and he has so many books!
He's learning every language in the world!
Do you know any Fulani?
Hello, how are you? I'm well
You're smart!
How is it going?
Are you doing well?
Yes, do you have any movies in French?
What kind of movies?
African French - the accent is nicer!
For you it's different. For us it's not our first language.
So there is an influence from other African languages?
I was saying that we don't need to travel!
You can learn every language in the world here in Columbus!
Indeed!
Have a good evening!

title: Two polyglots speak a dozen languages in a mall in Ohio: Benny and Moses level up!

comments.text:
Came here to comment on that video about the differences between Quebec and 
france. It's definitely true. French people are so arrogant about their 
language (Europe hates them). If you try to communicate in English they'll 
just reply in french more or less telling you to fuck off. ﻿
comments.author: MrQwerty2524

comments.text:
It's a cultural thing, you should study up on the culture of the country 
you are visiting before going there. The French don't like foreigners 
butchering their language and the workers there get a lot more respect in 
France. It's not like America where the customer is always right. Also they 
might seem less friendly because they don't smile at you when they pass by 
etc..., but it's culture is unlike the US  where we smile at everyone 
passing by.
Tip: treat them with respect, and try not to butcher their language and 
they will be a lot nicer. Of course this doesn't count every French person, 
some don't mind as much as others.

comments.author: Brad Boydston

comments.text:
I was answering the question asked. Their accents are lousy, and native 
Chinese speakers are generally very lenient in their evaluations of 
foreigners speaking Chinese.
comments.author: David Fishman

comments.text:
+David Fishman
Relax....you sound like a hater.
comments.author: Jason J.

comments.text: The Irish guy's accent in Spanish and French is close to perfect.
comments.author: Pandaligo

comments.text:
+May Mei I know that you are a native Chinese speaker. My point is that 
your standard for Chinese evaluation is too low. I think "I can understand 
it" is too easy of a standard. If someone speaks very poor English to me, I 
will probably still understand it, but it doesn't mean their English level 
is "OK"...it means I am native English speaker and they have bad English :) 

I've noticed both in China (where I live) and Korea (where I travel 
frequently) that people are very easily impressed by foreigners speaking 
their language (specifically Caucasian foreigners). They are so impressed 
that they tend to over-praise, which i think is for two reasons: 1. They 
are being polite. 2. They think their native language is 博大精深, so for any 
foreigner to learn any bit of it is impressive.  Because I am not Chinese 
and I do speak good Chinese, I'm not so easily impressed :D (But I only 
speak 2.5 languages, so these guys are still very impressive overall).
comments.author: David Fishman

comments.text:
+David Fishman​ I am a native Chinese Cantonese. Both Mandarin and 
Cantonese are my first languages. I understood what he said in Mandarin 
totally althought he has strong accent. However, I had a hard time to 
understand what he said in Cantoneses.
comments.author: May Mei

comments.text:
+May Mei I would give his Mandarin an "OK" just barely. It was like someone 
who's studied a few months of Chinese-full of awkward tones and overly 
formal constructions. 

When foreigners learn less common languages for study like Mandarin, native 
speakers tend to be excessively impressed and over-evaluate their 
abilities, perhaps a combination of politeness and true lack of a standard 
of comparison. When I first came to China 3.5 years ago, my Mandarin was 
dreadful, but I still got a slew of compliments on a daily basis. These 
days, with my fluent Mandarin, I feel like the reactions I get from cab 
drivers, waitresses etc...are pretty much the same. This has made me truly 
realize how generous their evaluation of my Mandarin was 3 years ago...
comments.author: David Fishman

comments.text:
His Khmer pronunciation wasn't good, but understandable.
Good job though.

comments.text:
17 and I speak English natively and French at a C1 level. I have studied 
Korean, Cantonese, Spanish and German. I am working towards becoming a 
A2/B1 level in all these languages by the end of 2015 in this order: German 
> Dutch > Spanish > Italian >Korean >Cantonese > Portuguese > Japanese. I 
use Duolingo... it is the best tool! Any other teenage language learners 
message me, we should be friends :)﻿

comments.author: Cadi Levox

comments.text: i know korean haha
comments.author: 문 서미 Mary.

comments.text:
Hey, that nice, but let me give you a tip!
I also started with Japanese and I have to admit that it was a jump into 
ice water. Its good that you want to learn so many languages, but Japanese 
and Russian took me 2 years to a good conversational level. Some months ago 
I satrted Moroccan Arabic (not the standard one) and also that is a pretty 
complicated language. Since this is the beginning of your journey, pick ONE 
language and later one, when you have more experience you can learn 2 at 
the same time. Because you have to think about it: A language journey will 
never end. You will never "complete" Japanese, you will learn more and more 
languages at the same time. Always keep that in the back of your head! ;)
comments.author: DownFlex

comments.text:
Do not buy Rosetta stone 1. So expensive 2. Flawed system, just search up a 
youtube video on why, there are probably hundreds. What I suggest is Teach 
Yourself, which I use for Russian, or Assimil or Routledge, all have good 
dialogues and come with cds, and for way less that Rosetta stone. Most 
people suggest two or more courses so you could probably buy all three with 
their cds for what you could spend on Rosetta stone.
comments.author: NaTs24

comments.text:
+David H Hey David, I'm 15 and I really want to learn Spanish, I love the 
culture, the country and the language, but I don't know how to get started. 
I've been thinking about purchasing Rosetta Stone, but after reading quite 
a few articles on Benny's blog, I've decided not to. Please tell me how you 
got started on learning these languages, and what was your method! It would 
be great if you could help me.
P.S: I currently speak both English and French fluently, but they are both 
technically my mother tongues.
comments.author: Gabriel Aaron

comments.author: NaTs24

comments.text:

comments.author: Stefan Malic

comments.text:
+Lestari Lahava Desde Dreaming big is fine. Dreaming unrealistically isn't. 
Honestly though, I prefer dreaming in smaller steps. For me it is much more 
effective to set a goal I can complete in the relative near future than 
something I can only accomplish in a lifetime. Also, dreaming small has 
another advantage. If you are thinking in a shorter time frame, usually, 
unless something extreme happens, circumstances won't affect your goal too 
much. However, who knows what might happen during the next 50 years? All 
those languages you listed, in 50 years you might have reasons not to learn 
half of them, and instead learn completely different ones. But hey, this 
might just be my Swedish way of thinking, good luck with all those 
languages!
comments.author: Mr Music

comments.text:
+LegendTheAnonymous why limit yourself?..like wonderboy said you have to 
dream big.
comments.author: Lelouch vi Britannia(Zero)

comments.text:
I'm 23 and currently learning spanish my next language is Arabic then

comments.author: 101wonderboy1

comments.text:
Wow, it's good to have goals, but maybe you should be more realistic. Why 
not just decide on 2 languages you want to learn, and once you actually 
achieve that, start thinking about learning more? Unless you decide to 
spend your entire life on learning languages, when you grow older, time 
will be limited and learning might become increasingly difficult.

comments.author: Tony Sar

comments.text:
I love how positive the mall folks' reactions are.  What people should take 
away from that is not that you and Moses are brilliant speakers, because 
you're not.  No, the takeaway is quite the opposite; you had thick accents 
and limited vocabularies, and *they still appreciated that you were trying 
to learn their language*.  That hurdle of "I'm not good enough yet" exists 
only in your mind.﻿

comments.author: bradley watkins

comments.text:
I've been reading your book and I'm addicted! as an avid youtuber, just had 
to come straight to your Youtube channel to watch this video, its really 
given me confidence! Totally subscribed you are such an inspiration to me! 
I'm starting an Italian Alevel and a Chinese speaking course  in September 
and I cant wait I adore languages :) the world needs more people like you, 
I will definitely be following your advice and techniques, all I can say I 
guess is, Thank you Benny! xXx n_n﻿

comments.text:

Hahaha. I dont really know why but it is true.﻿

comments.author: tekkmineharmony

comments.text:
quit asking where people are from, its rude.... ask them what their ethnic 
heritage or background is instead...you guys are cool, just a heads up!﻿
comments.author: EJ Ravago

comments.text:
I'm American and people ask me where I'm from all the time.  You can say 
that you are from Texas or something like that.  He's probably asking 
because he wants to make sure that they actually speak another language 
before he justs starts speaking another language to someone.  It might be a 
little more rude or "racist" then asking up front where someone is from.
comments.author: Jasmine Cook

comments.text:
+Brittany Ferrell
that's not true, english is my fourth language and i speak it with a 
perfect american accent. you can't even tell that it's not my first 
language. but you're right in some ways, sometimes you can tell just by 
hearing someone speak.
comments.author: Mehdi Mirzai

comments.text:
Oh yeah, I'm not denying that there are distinguishable accents. What I am 
suggesting, though, is that it is more polite to ask what their ethnic 
heritage is rather than what their origin is. That's all. On a side note, 
even if English is a second language, it does not necessitate one's origin. 
There are many second and third gen latino Americans who have English as 
their SECOND language...they are no less American than the next guy.
comments.author: EJ Ravago

comments.text:
+EJ Ravago I think in some cases however, when he asked the initial 
"icebreaker" he was able to hear an accent.. a non American Accent which 
probably aided in his curiosity to know where they may be from. In most 
cases, you can tell when English is a persons second language.
comments.author: Brittany Ferrell

comments.text:
It's rude because it assumes that a person is from another place. But true, 
people may have an answer, in places where it isn't multicultural or 
multigenerational, to the question, "Where are you from?" But places like 
the US, many ethnic minorities are from nowhere else other than America. 
They are American.
comments.author: EJ Ravago

comments.text: Keep in mind that for many cultures, this isn't a rude question.
comments.author: TeddyBearBonfire

comments.text:
:( My language is Latin but there is nobody to talk to :c

It is horrible because I can understand italian and spanish and french 
sometimes but they cannot understand me :'(﻿
comments.author: ๖ۣۜ♥๖̶tacokitten๖̶

comments.text:
hi benny I'm a big fan of yours. I noticed a lot of people were saying mean 
things, you shouldn't reply to mean comments because they will just post 
more, they like the attention. I'm fifteen and i've almost got two 
languages other than english learnt. only because i saw you and you proved 
it is possible to learn. :) anyway this was such a cool video, i love the 
sound of other languages being spoken even if i don't understand them. :)﻿
comments.author: Ashton L

comments.text:
get michel thomas's language program. he teaches  everything from japanese 
to french. its an audio book and he has a great way of teaching it. youtube 
michel thomas and there is a video of him teaching a bunch of british kids. 
and the results are truly amazing.
RIP MICHEL THOMAS﻿
comments.author: Ryan Lee

comments.text:
It doesn't matter if they have thick accents or if they sttuter, the most 
important is communication. See the reaction of people when they speak in 
their languages( laughters and smiles). I'm Brazilian, I would just love it 
if more people learned my language.﻿

comments.author: 41cookiesbabe

comments.text:
Racial profiling!! Lol, nah just kidding. This video is beyond inspiring, 
Benny! I really want to go out and try speaking to people in Japanese now! 
I really have no excuse at this point outside of shyness, especially after 
seeing you speak it with people after only a week. That's incredible. I'm 
going to try to start approaching any other languages I learn that way from 
now on :D﻿

comments.author: Frank B (Arxos)

comments.text:
I haven't seen Moses speak a single language well (besides English), his 
Spanish is probably worse than your average highschool student taking a 
class. Why try to learn so many languages when you can't have real 
communication in any of them?

Benny's Spanish was much better, at least...﻿
comments.author: Matt K

comments.text:
Moses has a new video where he walks around a supermarket and starts 
conversations with people in Swahili, Somali, Arabic, Korean, Chinese, 
Spanish, etc. He does a great job with them but I think he struggles with 
Spanish the most, for some reason. He spends like an hour and a half having 
lengthy conversations. So I think he is able to have real conversations.

comments.text:
I learnt Russian first listening to Babel Yak, then started watching 
Russian videos. Korean is a very tough but I like their writing systems 
though. I was bored at home and I decided to learn the alphabet. I am 
learning Mandarin Chinese right now.
comments.author: Drew Man

comments.text:
한글 is one of the easiest alphabets to learn, but the language is so much 
harder. I'm in the process of learning korean 한글 took about an hour to 
learn as did the sino-korean numbers. but the phases omg, the difference 
between the polite forms and the friendly forms are just uuuugh. but 
anyway, also learning spanish mandarin american sign language, and 
japanese. good luck to you :)

comments.text:
Super. Baigi labi runājat. Es pagaidām tikai 4 valodas zinu, saprotu  
runāju un rakstu. Bet nevaru normāli neko citu iemācīties. Pārāk daudz 
laika paņems. Ne dienu vai nedēļu bet pat mēnesi un jēga tomēr neatmaksājas.
Cik kopā ir tādi kas visas mācās? Un vai tiešām pietiekami? Vai tikai 
sarunu līmenī vai arī rakstīt? Ai bet šo ko rakstu tu laikam pārtulkosi ar 
google translate ja? :D﻿
